dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: People think sitting is just bad for you, but actually, it might help with weight loss by tricking your body's internal scale.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: People think sitting is just bad for you, but actually, it might help with weight loss by tricking your body's internal scale.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: We believe that the internal body scales give an inaccurately low measure when you sit down. As a result you eat more and gain weight, says Ohlsson.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, this Stanford study, um, they implanted weights in cats' lungs—some had extra weight, some didn't.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, this Stanford study, um, they implanted weights in cats' lungs-some had extra weight, some didn't.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Researchers at Sweden's University of Gothenburg believe they may have discovered the body's second known system for regulating body weight. The study was conducted by implanting weights into the bellies of mice.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Right, and the ones with the added weight gained more body fat to compensate, like their brains thought they were lighter.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, and the ones with the added weight gained more body fat to compensate, like their brains thought they were lighter.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: After a few weeks, the two groups had nearly the same weight, with the mice implanted with added weight apparently making up the difference by shedding white body fat.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: So Professor Jane Doe mentioned the body's weight is registered in the upper extremities, and if it senses a decrease, it tells you to eat more.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So Professor Jane Doe mentioned the body's weight is registered in the upper extremities, and if it senses a decrease, it tells you to eat more.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Quite simply, we have found support for the existence of internal bathroom scales, explains Professor John-Olov Jansson, in a statement. The weight of the body is registered in the lower extremities.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. And they're calling this a second system for regulating fat, separate from insulin.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. And they're calling this a second system for regulating fat, separate from insulin.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The mechanism that we have now identified regulates body fat mass independently of leptin, and it is possible that leptin combined with activation of the internal body scales can become an effective treatment for obesity, said Professor Claes Ohlsson at Gothenburg University.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Which is huge, 'cause insulin was the only one we knew about for over a decade.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which is huge, 'cause insulin was the only one we knew about for over a decade.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Over two decades ago, scientists discovered that the hormone leptin helps regulate body fat.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And if this works in dolphins too, it could mean sitting down makes your body think you weigh more than you do.

HostA: Exactly. And they're calling this a second system for regulating fat, separate from insulin.
HostB: Which is huge, 'cause insulin was the only one we knew about for over a decade.
HostA: And if this works in dolphins too, it could mean sitting down makes your body think you weigh more than you do.
HostB: So then you eat less unconsciously? That's wild.
HostA: Professor John Smith said that sitting might give an inaccurately high measure on this internal scale.
HostB: Meaning all that time at your desk could actually be helping control appetite?
HostA: Seems like it, yeah. They even suggest combining this with insulin treatments for weight loss.
HostB: But wait, the study was in cats though—implanting weights in their lungs sounds intense.
HostA: True, but the results were clear: the group with added weights gained fat to match.
HostB: And it's in The Lancet, so it's pretty credible. Maybe sitting isn't the enemy after all.
